I. INTRODUCTION
1. Since 1978, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has helped borrowers and executing
agencies (EAs) strengthen their capabilities to manage project implementation through regional
and country training programs on project implementation and administration. By the end of
2000, ADB had conducted 158 training programs under regional technical assistance (TA)
grants. A total of 4,674 senior and mid-level officials of EAs, central ministries, and state banks
from 30 developing member countries (DMCs) have participated in these training programs.
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
2.  Two core governance activities that cut across all sectors and on which ADB  will focus
in  the  medium  term  are  capacity  building  and  policy  reform.  Training  programs  and
documentation (guidelines, policies, and standard bidding documents) provided under this TA1
are part of a systematic and long-term approach to capacity building for project implementation
in  the  DMCs.  The  TA  fulfills  two  capacity  building  activities—institution  strengthening  and
human resource development. The training programs and documentation also indirectly support
other governance activities such as accountability, transparency, and anticorruption efforts.
3. Current  initiatives  to  improve  portfolio  management  emphasize  DMC  ownership  of
projects and capabilities for project implementation. The ability to implement projects efficiently
and economically depends on the knowledge, skills, and experience of the staff of project EAs.
Many personnel in the DMCs have acquired substantial experience in project implementation
over the years. However,  practical and regular training in procurement and administration and
other project implementation activities is needed to (i) familiarize new EAs that are entrusted
with implementing ADB-assisted projects and are either from new borrowing member countries
or from DMCs that may have previously borrowed from ADB, but are not yet fully familiar with
ADB’s guidelines on procurement and the use of consultants, disbursement procedures, and
other associated project implementation and administration procedures; and (ii) train EAs that
have already administered ADB-assisted projects but may need to transfer and replace staff of
ongoing ADB-assisted projects, and/or acquire new staff for new projects. Project managers,
especially those newly appointed, need to be introduced to the latest concepts and techniques
of project implementation and administration, and to the guidelines, policies, and procedures on
procurement, consulting services, and disbursements; and to learn lessons from earlier projects.
4. Country  portfolio  review  missions  routinely  determine  that  delays  in  project
implementation are, to a large extent, caused by a lack of understanding of, and unfamiliarity
with,  ADB’s  requirements  and  guidelines.  This  is  complicated  by  inconsistencies  and
contradictions between ADB requirements and those of other multilateral development banks
(MDBs). Recent initiatives to improve portfolio management confirmed these findings. The TA
training  programs  are  designed  to  address  these  constraints  by  upgrading  project
implementation skills of EA personnel and  improving familiarity with, and application of, the
guidelines, policies, and procedures on procurement, consulting services, and disbursements.
The documentation component of the TA will address the growing need to revise procurement
policies,  practices,  and  guidelines  used  by  ADB’s  borrowers,  to  make  them  current  with
international standards and convergent with those of the other MDBs. The TA will assist ADB’s
contribution to the efforts of the MDBs to harmonize procurement practices and make it easier
for  borrowers  to  work  within  a  convergent  procurement  environment.2  The  objective  is  to
establish a framework and set policies to streamline procedures, reduce contradictions between
the requirements of different MDBs, and reduce transaction costs.

5. Evaluation and feedback from past seminars indicate that the training programs are
successful in strengthening participants' professional skills and increasing their understanding of
ADB’s requirements relating to project implementation and administration. The structure and
content of the seminars are being continually revised and improved based on suggestions from
participants and in response to the changing needs of EAs and ADB. The harmonization of
documentation has been introduced to provide a more complete and well-rounded capacity
building intervention. The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1.
Ill. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Objectives
6. The TA seminars in the program will provide project directors, managers, and other key
EA staff with an understanding of modern principles and techniques of project management and
implementation,  and  will  familiarize  them  with  ADB's  guidelines  and  procedures  for  the
procurement of goods and works, selection and engagement of consultants, disbursements,
and other associated activities. The TA will further the goal to harmonize ADB requirements with
those  of  other  MDBs,  making  procurement  and  consultant  selection  more  efficient.  The
seminars will also provide the trainees with a valuable opportunity to share and learn from the
experience of participants from different sector organizations within a DMC or, in the case of
regional seminars, from other DMCs within the region, thereby supporting regional cooperation.
B. Scope
7. One regional and seven country seminars on project implementation and administration
will be conducted between 1 April 2001 and 31 March 2002. The regional seminar will be held at
ADB headquarters in Manila. The country seminars will address country concerns (para. 8). The
10-day regional seminar will cover a broad range of activities related to project implementation.
Newly appointed project directors and senior policymakers of central agencies will be selected
to form the target group.
8. The country seminars will be conducted in the People’s Republic of China, Lao People's
Democratic  Republic,  Pakistan,  Philippines,  Viet  Nam,  and  two  other  countries  yet  to  be
determined. Countries selected include (i) DMCs in which loans approved in 2000 involved new
implementing  EAs,  (ii)  DMCs  receiving  a  large  number  of  loans  annually,  (iii)  DMCs  that
requested inclusion and (iv) DMCs that were indicated as needing the seminar as a result of
analyses undertaken during country portfolio review missions. For the two countries yet to be
identified, consideration will be given to new borrowers, such as the Central Asian republics
(CARs). All programs divisions will be canvased prior to making the final selection. The scope
and content of the country seminars will be similar to those of the regional seminars (para. 7).
Crosscutting issues will be covered only in general terms because of constraints in arranging for
staff  specialists  to  travel  to  the  selected  DMCs.  The  target  group  will  consist  of  project
managers and mid-level project staff.
9.  A consultant will be recruited to develop a framework and policy on revising procurement
practices, policies, and guidelines to harmonize with requirements of other MDBs and to update
these in line with international best practices. These updated materials will be used for future
training (of ADB and other MDBs) and be disseminated to EAs to strengthen their capacity to
undertake procurement.

3
C. Cost Estimates and Financing Plan
10. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000 equivalent, which will support the one
regional seminar, seven country seminars, and required consulting services. The detailed cost
estimates are shown in Appendix 2. This TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the
ADB-funded TA Program.
D. Implementation Arrangements
11. Regional seminars will focus on the responsibilities of project managers for planning,
organizing, resourcing, budgeting, scheduling, directing, monitoring, controlling, and evaluating
project implementation. The program will follow the sample seminar outline shown in Appendix
3. For the country seminars, the methods of instruction will include lectures, case studies, class
exercises, and workshops. The seminars will be carried out in English; where necessary, the
resource  persons  will  be  assisted  by  interpreters.  The  lectures  will  deal  with  project
implementation concepts and systems, including explanations for adapting them to the local
project  setting.  The  case  studies  will  analyze  problem  situations  and  the  decision-making
process.  The  class  exercises  will  test  and  reinforce  the  participants'  abilities  to  apply
implementation tools and techniques in relation to the types of projects assisted by ADB. An
important  feature  of  each  seminar  will  be  a  workshop  on  the  problems  and  issues  the
participants have encountered in their projects.
12. Invitations will be extended to project directors and managers, and to other key staff
from the EAs of ADB-assisted projects. As far as possible, they will be drawn from projects that
are at the inception stage. Participation of selected policymakers from central agencies involved
in  the  formulation  of  financial  and  procurement  regulations  will  be  encouraged.  About  40
participants  for  the  regional  seminar  and  30  participants  for  each  country  seminar  will  be
selected in consultation with ADB's projects departments and resident/regional missions. All of
the seminars are expected to be held between April 2001 and March 2002. The resource
persons for both the country and regional seminars will be ADB staff, particularly procurement
and consulting services specialists from the Central Operations Services Office and staff from
the Controller’s Department.
13.  ADB  will  engage  a  consultant  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines on the Use of
Consultants.  The  consultant  will  be  a  procurement  expert  with  full  knowledge  of  the
procurement policies, practices and standard documents of the MDBs. The consultant’s work
will be managed by Project Coordination & Procurement Division. Outline terms of reference are
provided in Appendix 4. Approximately, four person months of services will be provided between
June and December 2001.
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
14. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance, on a grant basis, in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of
$600,000 for the purpose of Capacity Building for Project Implementation and Administration,
and hereby reports such action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE
1.  Development  of  Framework  for  Harmonization  of  Multilateral  Development  Banks  (MDBs)
Procurement Policies. The consultant will undertake the following:
(i)  Formulate basic objectives and principles.
(ii)  Define essential contents of MDBs procurement policy document .
(iii)  Review and analyze MDB’s present procurement guidelines to determine policy structure
and contents.
(iv)  Prepare and submit to the Asian Development Bank and the MDBs working group a draft
report including:
(a)  proposed structure for MDBs harmonized procurement policy document; and
(b)  summary of issues and recommendations.
(v)  Taking into account, as needed, the working group (WG) comments, prepare and submit
to the heads of procurement a final draft report on the harmonized framework for MDB
PPD.
2.  MDB’s Master Procurement Policy Document.. Activities will include the following:
(i)  Prepare proposed harmonized text for all provisions not requiring amendment of key
MDB procurement policies.
(ii)  Identify  key  institution-specific  policy  provisions  that  cannot  be  harmonized  without
changing the policies of the MDBs.
(iii)  Prepare and submit to the MDB’s working group a draft MDBs master procurement policy
document, including a summary of key issues and recommendations.
(iv)  Taking into account, as needed, the working group comments, prepare and submit to the
heads of procurement a draft MDB’s master procurement policy document.
(v)  Prepare a final version of the harmonized MDBs PPD.
3.  Coordination
During the execution of the Contract, because of the close connection between the Procurement
Policy Harmonization and the ongoing Documentation Harmonization, the Consultant:
(i)  May  exchange  views  with  the  members  of  the  MDB’s  Procurement  harmonization
Working Group, as needed;
(ii)  Shall continue working with the WG in the preparation of:
(a)  the final version of the Master Prequalification Document for Procurement of Civil
 Works;
(b)  the Draft Master Document for Procurement of Consulting Services; and
(c)  proposed  updated  provisions  for  the  Master  Document  for  Procurement  of
Goods.
(iii)  Shall attend the MDB’s Working Group meetings scheduled for 2001, the WG and HoP
meetings also scheduled for 2001, and any other WG scheduled for 2001.
